title: Starting Fire with Bow and Drill
brief: Create fire through friction using a bow and drill system with proper technique.
steps: Step 1: Make a fire board: seasoned softwood, 2.5 cm thick, 10 cm wide, with a 2 cm depression near the edge and V-shaped notch underneath.
Step 2: Create a drill: straight seasoned hardwood, 2 cm diameter, 25 cm long, with round top and blunt bottom.
Step 3: Fashion a bow: resilient green stick 2.5 cm diameter with cordage tied from end to end without slack.
Step 4: Find a socket: stone or hardwood with slight depression to hold drill and apply pressure.
Step 5: Place tinder bundle under the V-shaped notch in the fire board.
Step 6: Put one foot on fire board, loop bowstring over drill, place drill in depression.
Step 7: Hold socket on top of drill with one hand, saw bow back and forth with other hand to spin drill.
Step 8: Once smooth motion is established, apply more downward pressure and work bow faster.
Step 9: Continue until hot black powder grinds into tinder and creates a spark.
Step 10: Blow gently on tinder until it ignites into flame.
warnings: This method is exhaustive and requires significant practice to master.
Do not use wood lying on the ground - it lacks sufficient friction properties.
Ensure all materials are properly prepared before attempting.
Stop immediately if drill begins to smoke excessively without producing ember.
